As a consequence of this theorem we have the following stability estimate with respect to the maximum-norm,where we use the notation of Sect.1.2 
Theorem2.2.Let  $A$  be asin(2.1)and（2.2).If  $u\in\mathcal{C}^{2}$  ，then 

$$
\|u\|_{\mathcal{C}}\leq\operatorname*{max}\left\{|u(0)|,|u(1)|\right\}+C\|A u\|_{\mathcal{C}}.
$$
 
Theconstant  $C$  dependsonthecoefficientsof  $\pmb{A}$  butnoton  $\pmb{u}$  
Proof.We shall bound themaximaof  $\pm u$  Weset  $\phi(x)={\bf e}^{\lambda}-{\bf e}^{\lambda x}$  anddefine thetwofunctions 

$$
v_{\pm}(x)=\pm u(x)-\|A u\|c\,\phi(x).
$$
 
Since  $\phi\geq0$  in  $\varOmega$  and  $\begin{array}{r}{A\phi=c\mathrm{e}^{\lambda}+(a\lambda^{2}+(a^{\prime}-b)\lambda-c)\mathrm{e}^{\lambda x}\geq1}\end{array}$  in  $\bar{\varOmega}$  ,if  $\lambda>0$  is chosen sufficiently large,we have,with such a choice of  $\lambda$  

$$
\pmb{\mathcal{A}}v_{\pm}=\pm\pmb{\mathcal{A}}u-\|\pmb{\mathcal{A}}u\|_{C}\pmb{\mathcal{A}}\phi\leq\pm\pmb{\mathcal{A}}u-\|\pmb{\mathcal{A}}u\|_{C}\leq0\quad\mathrm{in~}\Omega.
$$
 
Theorem2.1(ii)thereforeyields 

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\underset{\bar{\Omega}}{\operatorname*{max}}(v_{\pm})\leq\operatorname*{max}\big\{v_{\pm}(0),v_{\pm}(1),0\big\}}\\ &{\qquad\qquad\leq\operatorname*{max}\big\{\pm u(0),\pm u(1),0\big\}\leq\operatorname*{max}\big\{|u(0)|,|u(1)|\big\},}\end{array}
$$
 
because  $v_{\pm}(x)\leq\pm u(x)$  for all  $\pmb{x}$  .Hence 

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\underset{\bar{\Omega}}{\operatorname*{max}}(\pm u)=\underset{\bar{\Omega}}{\operatorname*{max}}\left(v_{\pm}+\|\mathcal{A}u\|_{C}\,\phi\right)\leq\underset{\bar{\Omega}}{\operatorname*{max}}(v_{\pm})+\|\mathcal{A}u\|_{C}\|\phi\|_{C}}\\ &{\qquad\qquad\leq\operatorname*{max}\big\{|u(0)|,|u(1)|\big\}+C\|\mathcal{A}u\|_{C},\quad\mathrm{with~}C=\|\phi\|_{C},}\end{array}
$$
 
which completes the proof 
FromTheorem2.2 we immediately conclude the uniqueness of a solution of (2.1). In fact, if  $\mathbfit{\textbf{2}}$  and  $\pmb{\mathcal{U}}$  were two solutions,then their difference  ${\pmb w}={\pmb u}-{\pmb v}$  would satisfy  $\mathbfcal{A}\mathbfcal{w}=\mathbf{0}$   $\begin{array}{r}{\pmb{w}(0)=\pmb{w}(1)=\mathbf{0}.}\end{array}$  ,and hence  $\|w\|_{\cal C}=0$  ,sothat  $\pmb{u}=\pmb{v}$  
More generally, if  $\pmb{u}$  and  $\boldsymbol{\upsilon}$  are two solutions of (2.1) with right hand sides  $f$  and  $\pmb{g}$  and boundary values  $\mathbf{\mathit{u}}_{0},\mathbf{\mathit{u}}_{1}$  and  $v_{0},v_{1}$  ,respectively,then 

$$
\|u-v\|_{C}\leq\operatorname*{max}\left\{|u_{0}-v_{0}|,|u_{1}-v_{1}|\right\}+C\|f-g\|_{C}.
$$
